I assume its for ember-cli addon ?
<@U03SSL0FM>: confirm

topic: Discussion around pact file testing for ember-cli
text: <@U043AB2QT|aaron> set the channel topic: Discussion around pact file testing for ember-cli
Yup.
I don't have time right now but I can give you a brain dump of where I'm at and the concept and how I see it working when I get a chance.
Essentailly....Think VCR for ruby...Then turn it upside down.
sounds good
<@U03V5PXL0|rik> has joined the channel
so the idea is you could run your acceptance test suite and it will generate a Pactfile
which you can then use to test the server implementation
Yep.
There are two sides....The generation of the pact file from the client side......Then the verification of the api against the pact file

Also, I think, instead of generating the pact file every time you run the client side tests, it might just prime pretender with what's in the pact file....And possibly warn if you are making requests that aren't covered by the pact file..
Dunno...That part isn't quite clear to me yet.....
Need to start building it and seeing how it all feels.
Been chatting to Sam Selikoff who wrote ember-cli-mirage about this....He's interested....And I think we can leverage some of this experience with that addon here.
It may well just be an extra feature in that addon....Who knows?
This site that <@U03V8V08M> posted will give a good background on the concept: <https://github.com/realestate-com-au/pact>

attachments.title: realestate-com-au/pact
attachments.text: pact - Enables consumer driven contract testing, providing a mock service and DSL for the consumer project, and interaction playback and verification for the service provider project.

text: for some apps I can imagine you might want to generate the Pactfile from the server side
and verify the client against it
but that’s roadmap stuff
the most compelling case for now is UI-driven API design
IMHO

> the most compelling case for now is UI-driven API design

Exactly....That's kind of the point.
